text.p: These are the leading stories in the Beirut press on Thursday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
-A coalition between Amal and Hizbollah in south Lebanon polls has been cooked in secret.
-Beirut relieved after Oslo assures it that the hijacker of the Bulgarian plane was not armed.
-The Council of Maronite Bishops: "The elections showed that our democracy is retreating".
-Economy Minister Jaber promised to lower the price of bread as the price of wheat has begun to fall.
-More that 522,000 voters to choose 23 south Lebanon representatives to parliament in the polls on Sunday.
-Islamist MP Yakan says: "The elections are unconstitutional and illegal".
-Israeli jets stage mock raids over south Lebanon.
-A poll on the south Lebanon elections shows that 48 percent will stick to choosing the announced lists of candidates.
-Lebanon bought $170 million worth of industrial machinery from Germany in the first seven months of 1996.
-Sheikh Fadlallah, spiritual leader of Lebanon's pro-Iranian Moslem militants, calls for a coalition between Hizbollah and Amal in the south Lebanon polls.
-State Minister al-Khalil urges the residents of Israel's south Lebanon occupation zone to vote in the polls.
